instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00430: What is 820-00430? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-4668: What is 820-4668? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=verdana]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A first LED light comes on, I have never worked on an iMac board so I dont even know how to power this thing with a power supply, boardview and schematics are nowhere to be found.

Board is clean no visible damage anywhere, board 3v battery was replaced but still no startup.

Any guidance will be greatly appreciated.[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Maybe <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematic helps you a bit.
Taking this as guide, only need to connect 12V at pins 4-6/J6900.
If first LED (LE0301) stays on, board is in S5 state.

If CMOS coin cell is removed, board should start by itself.
Check if you get pulse at any S3/S0 power rail (big coils).
I recommend you to change <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: Thanks, battery removed board not starting, no pulsing on big coils, replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR> still nothing, <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> was getting really hot removed it for now as I think the iMac should start even without that one, but nada!

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
If <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> is same audio power, like in schematic, board can start without it.
It also means that board achieves S4 state, if that chip heats; is on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> rail.
Can you confirm presence of such voltage on its coil?
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> should be high.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: Yes <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> is audio related, after removing <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> present on its coil, in fact I am making it to <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> checking <TRANSISTOR>Q4020</TRANSISTOR> now but I seem to be stock.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
I think Im close to finding the problem,

<CHIP>U8450</CHIP>
1. 12v
2.3.2v
3. 0v
4. 0v
5.12v
6. 12v
7. 23v
8. 3.3v

<CHIP>U6970</CHIP>
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]1. 12v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]2.3.4v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]3. 0v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]4. 0v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]5.12v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]6. 12v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]7. 22v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
[LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]8. 3.8v

I don't have any boards that have those chips so I cannot replace them yet, I will order them once I know that is the problem, thanks for all the tips so far, if I fix this one this will be my first iMac fixed.[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8450</CHIP> looks good.
It doesn't fail, just <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR>.
Which is also good if you get <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>.
And of course U/<TRANSISTOR>Q6970</TRANSISTOR> both good, as you already got S5 state.
When corresponding MOSFET is bad, you will not get 22V output from <CHIP>U6970</CHIP>/8450.

Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at least.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
The 23v made me think something was wrong since the schematics show 12v on that line.

[LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT] is 3.3v steady I dont know how to trigger [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> but it is 3.4v steady also <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>. is 3.4v steady[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is steady high, you should get all S3 voltages; check that.
You should see a drop pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

"I dont know how to trigger"
Imagine something like pressing power button; J5120 can be used...

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: I do [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]see a drop pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> or when "pressing power button"[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Then all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals must pulse.
And of course, corresponding voltages should pulse too.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: None of [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> pulse, the voltage is there but no pulse either with a trigger on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> or a power button press.[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: Ok Im now at <SIGNAL>PP0V6_S3_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> that power line is not present in <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> pin 3 but present on XW7325 but with 1.2v and not 0.6v as the schecmatic shows, Im hoping this will be the culprit...

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
"None of[COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit] <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> pulse, the voltage is there but no pulse[/FONT][/COLOR]"
That is good, if you have stable levels.
I said to check for pulse, in case no stable high level...

<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S3_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> comes from pin 3/<CHIP>U7300</CHIP>.
Maybe you didn't have good contact when measured.

Looks like you have all voltages on the board.
Confirm that for CPU coils.
Check for USB activity with mouse/keyboard.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
[LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S3_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> not present on pin 3 of <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> tripple checked it, even gave it a re-solder and nothing, whats also strange is that pin 5 is 0.6v rather than 1.2v as mentioned in the schematics.[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

<SIGNAL>REG_PHASE_P1V05S0_L</SIGNAL> is 0v on its coil same with <SIGNAL>REG_PHASE_CPUVCC_1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>REG_PHASE_CPUVCC_2</SIGNAL>

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
So no CPU VCORE, board cannot work.
Check for enable signals at pins 16/17 of <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>.
Also check if receives 5V at pin 12.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> pin 12 5v, pin 16 3.3v pin 17 0v

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Then you cannot have 0.6V at DDRVTT yet, as pin 17 is not enabled.
But you must have 1.2V at L7310; confirm that.

DDRVTT is enabled by CPU.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: Confirmed, I do have 1.193v at [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]L7310[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V5_S0</SIGNAL>?
Also check all voltages from page 63.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is 0.005 and <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is 0v

Power rails missing are <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_DDR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPCPUVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Are you sure???
You just confirmed 1.2V at L7310 before...

threads.message: yes sorry [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_DDR</SIGNAL> are present but not <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPCPUVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>/500 voltages.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Looks like missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>; check that.
Also check <SIGNAL>REG_P1V2_S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>.
Be sure =<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> and <RESISTOR>R7340</RESISTOR> OK.

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
[LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> present 3.3v [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_REG_P1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 3.3v at <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> <RESISTOR>R7340</RESISTOR> is 19.49k checking real value now as I dont see that resistor on the schematic

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: Whats strange is that [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<RESISTOR>R7340</RESISTOR> is ok at 19.49k but [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT][COLOR=#007000]<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_REG_P1V2_S3</SIGNAL> is 3.3v not 1.2v[/COLOR]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Mmmm, I just saw that in fact you didn't post any voltage for pins 8/9/10 of <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>.
I was reading values from <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> instead.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_EN_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PM_EN_S0</SIGNAL> is 3.3v at <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message: [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PM_EN_S0</SIGNAL> is 3.3v at <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> but [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT][COLOR=#007000]<SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P3V3_S0_R</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> is 0.013v[/COLOR]

threads.title: iMac 21.5" Mid Late 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no clue
threads.message:
Yeas, because missing <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_REG_P1V05_S0</SIGNAL> signal; which is same as <SIGNAL>REG_P1V05S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_S0</SIGNAL> presence suppose to get some S0 voltages controlled by this signal.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P5V_S0</SIGNAL>
